title: 112_s3341
content: The Act is titled the "Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review Act of 2012". It focuses on the Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review. The Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review Act of 2012 mandates the Secretary of State to conduct a quadrennial diplomacy and development review every four years to examine and make recommendations on the national diplomacy and development policy of the United States for the next four-year period. The Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review Act of 2012 requires the Secretary of State to conduct a review every four years to assess the national diplomacy and development policy of the United States. This includes priorities, programs, assets, capabilities, budget, policies, and authorities of the Department of State and United States Agency for International Development. Consultation with relevant federal agencies is also necessary during the review process. The Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review Act of 2012 mandates a review every four years by the Secretary of State to evaluate US national diplomacy and development policy. This involves assessing priorities, programs, assets, capabilities, budget, policies, and authorities of the Department of State and USAID. Consultation with relevant federal agencies, including the Attorney General, Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Agriculture, Commerce, CEO of Millennium Challenge Corporation, Director of National Intelligence, and others, is required. The Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review Act of 2012 mandates a review every four years by the Secretary of State to evaluate US national diplomacy and development policy. This involves assessing priorities, programs, assets, capabilities, budget, policies, and authorities of the Department of State and USAID, in consultation with relevant governmental and nongovernmental entities, private sector representatives, academics, and policy experts. The review outlines the national diplomacy and development policy and strategic framework, prioritizing critical areas, capabilities, and resources across agencies. The curr_chunk focuses on the interagency cooperation, preparedness of Federal assets, infrastructure, budget plan, diplomacy and development policies, roles of international organizations, and budget requirements for successful execution of mission priorities. The curr_chunk focuses on identifying the budget plan needed for mission priorities, assessing organizational alignment, and reviewing the effectiveness of management mechanisms for executing strategic priorities outlined in the quadrennial diplomacy and development review. The effectiveness of the quadrennial diplomacy and development review has improved. The Secretary of State must report to Congress on the review's requirements, acquisition strategy, and expenditure plan. The Secretary of State must report to Congress on the quadrennial diplomacy and development review, including results, threats to national security interests, underlying assumptions, and any other relevant matters. The report must be made publicly available. The Secretary of State may establish an Office of Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review within the Department of State to assist in conducting the review. The Secretary should also inform the Foreign Affairs Policy Board of the review progress and provide a final report to the Board upon completion. The Foreign Affairs Policy Board will assess the review and submit it to the Secretary for inclusion in the report. The Senate passed the legislation on September 22, 2012. Attest: NANCY ERICKSON, Secretary.
